data.title: Lens question for Nikon Zf
data.meta_description: I have 2x Nikon Zf on order (brown and red). I have been using Sony FF for longer than I can remember for my wedding business and am excited to com...
data.text:
gheller

Offline

    

: Off

p.1 #1 · p.1 #1 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

I have 2x Nikon Zf on order (brown and red). I have been using Sony FF for longer than I can remember for my wedding business and am excited to come full circle (started with a Nikon FM a few centuries ago)

I *love* my current lens setup for weddings and want to duplicate it as close as possible once the Nikons arrive.

I shoot one body with the Sigma 85mm 1.4 and the other with the Tamron 28-200

Not really familiar with what lenses will work with the new Zf, but I think this will work:

Sigma 85mm 1.4 with the FTZII adapter

Nikon Nikon NIKKOR Z 24-200mm VR

Anything glaring that I am missing?

Excited to participate here in this forum and learn

Thanks!

Greg

Just want to make sure

swifty168

Offline

  

: Off

p.1 #2 · p.1 #2 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

Hi Greg, just trying to understand you correctly.

Which Sigma 85mm f/1.4 do you have? If its in E-mount then you would use one of the third party E to Z adapters and not the FTZ I or II. Youd need to check compatibility list for the adapter you end up buying.

But since youre starting from scratch, I might suggest you try all Z lenses.

The Z 85mm f/1.8 is stellar but only f/1.8.

The Z 85mm f/1.2 is stellar-er/est but is bulky and expensive and may not balance well on a Zf. Might be ok with the extra grip extension though.

gheller

Offline

    

: Off

p.1 #3 · p.1 #3 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

Sorry, I will try to clarify. I use (and love) the Sigma f/1.4 on my Sony. I want to buy the Nikon mount version, but seems like I will need the FTZ adapter (which I am fine with).

Yes, I want 1.4 and don't want the weight (or cost) of the 1.2

I am guessing the NIKKOR Z 24-200mm VR will work right on the body.

Thanks!

greg

swifty168

Offline

  

: Off

p.1 #4 · p.1 #4 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

Ahh ok.

Firstly any native Z mount lens from Nikon will be 100% compatible with Z bodies including the Zf. So yes, 24-200 Z will work perfectly.

Secondly only Nikon AFS F-mount lenses are guaranteed to be fully compatible with Z bodies via FTZ. But having said that the majority of third party lenses for F mount also have no issues and those with issues are usually rectified via firmware.

Check this article:

https://photographylife.com/nikon-ftz-adapter-lens-compatibility/amp#sigma-brand-lenses

The Sigma 85mm f/1.4 is listed as fully compatible on the latest firmware.

Now the Zf is a new body so it may break a few things for third party lenses initially but theyre usually resolved via firmware. Theres no way to 100% guarantee things for third party lenses however.

AcuteShadows

Offline

   

: On

p.1 #6 · p.1 #6 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

You will probably need f/1.4 only for depth of field, not light.

Check the Nikkor Z f/1.8 S lenses, they have amazing quality in a lightweight package.

If you need shallow depth of field, consider the Nikkor Z 50mm f/1.2, and crop a little if necessary.

Also, I'd consider the Nikkor Z 28-75mm f/2.8 and the Nikkor Z 24-120mm f/4 S, unless you really need 200mm. At f/6.3, the 24-200mm may be too slow at the long end.

The Nikkor Z 24-120mm f/4 S is also a great (near) macro lens, as it has a 1/2.6 magnification at minimum focus distance.

Desmolicious

Offline

     

: Off

p.1 #7 · p.1 #7 · Lens question for Nikon Zf

gheller wrote:

Thank you very much for the information (and the link).

I may check out the Z 85mm f/1.8 ~ perhaps the weight and compatibility factor will outweigh the faster 1.4

greg

I would 100% get the Z 85 1.8 over a 3rd party 1.4 and FTZ adapter. I use the FTZ on my Z7, and pretty much it spoils the handling. It's for if you already have F mount lenses. I wouldn't buy it so I could also buy F mount lenses to use!

And you'll never have to worry about possible compatibility issues.
